Panellus mitis - Панеллюс нежный - Soft bread-rust - Weichporling 10/17/09—9/23/22

Panellus mitis is a small, fan-shaped mushroom that grows in clusters on decaying wood, often on the branches of hardwood trees. It is found in temperate forests throughout North America, Europe, and Asia. The fruiting bodies of Panellus mitis are thin and flexible, with caps that are up to 4 cm in diameter and a few millimeters thick. The caps are typically orange-brown to reddish-brown in color and have a velvety or fuzzy texture. The gills on the underside of the cap are closely spaced and often forked near the stem. Chemical analysis of Panellus mitis has revealed the presence of several bioactive compounds, including polysaccharides, ergosterol, and ergothioneine. These compounds have been shown to have immunomodulatory, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties, and may have potential for use in the development of new drugs. The spores of Panellus mitis are elliptical in shape and measure 5-7 µm in length. They are white in color and have a smooth surface. The spore print of the mushroom is pale yellow. Panellus mitis is not commonly used for culinary purposes, but it is sometimes used in traditional Chinese medicine for its supposed health benefits. In addition, it has been studied for its potential use in the bioremediation of heavy metals and other pollutants in the environment. Overall, Panellus mitis is a fascinating and potentially useful mushroom that is worthy of further study.

Panellus mitis - Панеллюс нежный - Soft bread-rust - Weichporling
